transcript.content: This is audible.
Welcome to number two in this second series of the Ricky Gervais show with me, Ricky Gervais. Hello. Stephen Merchant.
Hello.
And Carl Pilkington. Well, I've been away. I had a little bit of a. An express tour of America, L.A. and New York. And they're all talking about one thing out there. Carl Pilkington.
Really?
Yeah. I hooked up with the Simpsons lot. They all listened to it on their. Their ipods. I went down to the American office to keep an eye on, you know, things.
Check it, check it.

Well, as we get money for old rogue doing next to nothing, I thought I'd show them a face. They're big fans, Carl. I met up with Jason Bateman, you know, Arrested Development. And he knows how stupid you are. David Letterman knows what an idiot you are mentioned on the Letterman show. I mean, unbelievable. David Bowie listens and they're all listening to little Carl Pilkington. I think when I think of people like that, like pretty much geniuses in their field. But when I think of Bowie listen to it, I still think of him as 26, dressed as.
Dressed as Ziggy.
Yeah.
With a pair of those big 70s headphones.
Yeah. He's going, hey, mom, can you turn the TV down? Listen to Pilkington.
Absolutely.

I love his kooky outlet look on life. And Christopher Guest. Now, Christopher Guest empathizes with you a little bit because obviously everyone else sort of knows how stupid you are and not understanding concepts like, you know, the infinite amount of monkeys. But he empathizes with that because he thinks sometimes he. He thinks that he sometimes doesn't understand concepts that seem obvious to other people. However, I think he's being polite. I don't think you've got a lot in common with him because he did all the other genius stuff. You know, what you did was do the washing up with your pants pulled down slightly. You know, it didn't have the same effect.
To say it's not been as influential as Spinal Tap.
Oh, wait for Guffman.
No. Unless people, maybe that's sweeping the nation now. Maybe if someone sees someone nude in a room opposite their house, they immediately get their cock out.

They go, genius. That is genius. Well, I did an appearance at the Oxonian Society in New York. It's a Princeton college run event. And they have like, academics, artists, political figures, they have heads of industry, they had world leaders, they've had Princess of Jordan. And there was a Q A afterwards. And one of the questions was, is monkey news coming back?
Yeah.
In that sort of forum I mean, it's.
I believe they also asked that of Bill Clinton.
Yeah. Now, Carl, is monkey news coming back?
I mean, maybe. It depends what goes on out there. It's gone a bit quiet on it.
On the monkey front.

Yeah, that, you know, I don't know if they're aware or whatever that's being covered, but it's just like, you know, you can't make news, can you? All these news channels. That's the problem with it. They've committed to saying, we're a news channel. You gotta find news. Well, don't do it like that. I'd say put something else on. If now it's going on. Cartoons, just, just.
Is there often no news in the world? On the planet Earth with 6 billion people, is there ever a day where they go, no, nothing.
But, but I'm just saying the news is, what is it, about half an hour long?
It depends! There's news channels that are 24 hours, but you're thinking of one specific news program that's on in your house.
Yeah, but I'm just saying it's half an hour, how much of that?

No, no, no. He's like, again, again, you don't, I've told you that not all news programs are half an hour by definition, but you go, "Anyway, it's half an hour." Again, you didn't listen to me. Why do you think all news programs are half an hour? They're not.
I'm just saying how much of that do we actually need to know about?

But we don't need to know about any news. I mean, outside, sort of dangerous situation, it's interesting, it's entertainment. People want to be aware, people want to be hooked up. I mean, I don't, you know, watch the news much or read papers, but it's funny, when I'm away, I do. I suppose it's because you want to feel connected with what's yours. It's that feeling of being part of society, isn't it?
No, but there's places, say, like, there's places where they don't have telly, right. And they're not watching the news. They're still getting on with life.
Yes, they are.
And they're bogged down with their own problems, which is the way it should be. Say, like, at the moment, I've got a leak in the bathroom, right.
Have you?
It's doing me head in.
Ricky laughs

So I put the telly on to get away from all that. Then you put the news on. They go, there's a, you know, bad weather in whatsit. You go, oh, don't tell me that as well. I like it when you hear about inventions that are coming out or, you know, stuff they're doing in science.
But you told me the other day that you thought everything that needs to be invented has been invented. Something they said in 1900. But, so what do you think?
Yeah, I mean, they are sort of playing around now. Like, if they've said they've made like a heart now that can be bunged into a body if yours isn't working and keep you going.
But why is that? Why is a heart that you can bung into someone to save their life, why is that a bad thing?
Just because it's another thing in it that's, we're meant to die, from the year dot, things live, you have your bit, you knock about, and then you die.
Steve laughs
If you're gonna live forever, how do you plan stuff, right? That's the way I look at it.
Sure.
You sort of go --
How big would your diary be?
Well, that diary would become intimidating, wouldn't it?
This is what I'm saying --
Fill that in for the rest of eternity.
You get bored, you get bored with living forever, and, you know --
But I agree with you.
You get bored of people. You'd have to keep making new mates, wouldn't you? Because you've discussed everything by the time you're about 110.
Steve laughs
So it's kind of like --
Karl, you have the same concepts that you worked out and decided that were true at about 10 I think.
I look at life like, like a --
Box of chocolate?
Like a big book.
Ricky laughs
Right, okay, yeah
And, you know, sometimes you get halfway through it and you go, even though I've been, you know, I've been enjoying it, I've had enough. Give us another book.
No, no, no, no. Your metaphor, analogy, whatever you're trying to create there falls down with, "Let's have another book."
Yeah

No, no, no. You can either opt out of life or stick with it till the end. You can't go, "Ahh, be someone else now." You can't do that. I know you think you can, and I think in your world you can, you know, you possibly be injected into an old woman's head when you've had enough and you come out a little baby.
What I mean is, at the moment, you know, my life, I'm gonna live to 74, 75. So, yeah, I'm probably on page. What am I on? A book that's got about.....200...
This is painful, Steve. This is really painful. Sorry, carry on.
I'm on....say if my book's got.. err, 300 pages in it.
Yeah
Few...few pictures and that
Steve laughs
It's a picture book. That's the great thing about Carl's like, it's a book for children.
It's a pop up book. And it just. Every time he pops in he goes "Alright"
I'm probably on like page about 170.
Ricky laughs
So specific! He's gonna die at 74. He's reading a book with a few pictures in with 300 pages and he's on 170. Go on then.
So, right, if the book was too thick, right, and there was loads more...
Let me tell you, this book is way too thick.
If the book was more thick yeah..
The book could not be thicker.
If there was loads more pages left, I'd go, I can't be bothered reading on.
Ricky laughs
Right, okay, let him finish the analogy.
Well he must've known that when he saw the book. You don't..
He's got to finish this analogy, otherwise we're going to be here all night.
Listen, he must have known how many pages there were when he got the book out of the library.
Yeah, but the way they write books, they paint in pictures more at the beginning. You're going, this is good. And then it gets a bit boring as it goes on, doesn't it?
Okay, well that works. So you're saying that you were young...
No, it doesn't work. You just accepted that that's what all books are like.

No, but there's a little bit of poetry in that because he's sort of..he's actually saying that when he was young, his whole life was ahead of him, he couldn't wait, the whole world, the promise that he was given of this world. And now he's a bit jaded and he's more cynical and he realizes the world hasn't got as much to offer him as he thought it was. Is that what you meant?
Yeah.
Liar.
Ricky snickers

Well, Rick, you're not the only one who's been away. I know you've been off working, but I at long last have taken a bit of leisure time. And uh.. you've probably heard of the Rio de Janeiro Carnival. Only one of the hottest, you know, events in the world calendar. Imagine me down there. Rio, you can imagine, did not know what hit it.
Oh, God Almigh... Were you like Paul 'The Party Animal' Parker?
He would not have been able to keep up if he was with me.
God, what did you do? What did you get up to?
Let me tell you right now, day one, I almost drowned. Day two, I got a foot infection and spent the day in the hospital. And the rest of time I had diarrhea.
Ricky laughs
So that's, that's, that was a hell Of a. That was a hell of a time.
Carnival.

Yeah. Yeah, I did. I was able to watch some of the carnival on TV and it looked brilliant. It looked amazing. I didn't actually....it's difficult to make out because the TV wasn't actually in my room..
Ricky laughs

Umm..because in an effort to save money, I wasn't staying in a hotel. I was staying with a bunch of other people in some kind of like someone's flat that they let out. And so I had to look, I had to watch the tv, like from my window watching a neighbor's tv. And of course when they changed the channel, you know, often during the juicy bits, I couldn't see anything...and umm, but they look really good. I'm bunged up at the moment just so I can get through the show, but I've just been on a 12 hour flight. And it is terrifying being on a flight when you know that any moment you could go. Because you know, the problem is sometimes the toilet's free and sometimes you got to queue up. And the worst bit is that that sort half an hour just before you land. When they say the toilets are out of bounds now
Ricky laughs

I tell ya I went twice before that in quick succession. The woman sat next to the toilet, she was...she didn't know what was going on, the noises and stuff, you know.  And I was...because I was really panicky, and..and so of course then on the whole flight as we're landing, I'm just, I'm really petrified because I'm thinking this could...and Ipacked a pair of underpants and jeans in my bag in my hold all just in case it all went. And I was really. Because I hate flying anyway and I hate landing because it's the most terrifying moment of the journey. Then it really was rumbling. I was thinking, I gotta get out of here. Of course, you know, you know, when you're in a hurry, everything's suddenly...everything makes you angry! The little old lady in front of me who's just hobbling along off the gang plank..GET OUT OF MY WAY!
With your bad hips, I know you've been through a war, but get out of my way.

And just anyone who could have even passes you. And so I managed to get there just in time, got into the. And it all went off. Man alive, it was, it was grim. But that was not anything compared with the first couple of days. It was the first day I went for a walk. And of course Ipanema beach is famous. I mean, obviously the girl from Ipanema, one of the most famous songs in the world. And it's. Ipanema beach is famous for just the beautiful, beautiful people that gather there. And it is extraordinary. I mean, the people are remarkable. There's so many beautiful women in Rio. It made me angry. I was angry that these women were so attractive in that, you know, none of them were even looking at me. So. But anyway, I'm on the beach because I was shopping and I needed a wee, right, and we went for a quick impromptu swim and I thought, oh, we in the sea.
Just think of him on this beach, right, with diarrhea.
Well, I'm wearing great big long shorts because I'm not going to try and compete with these boys because they are.
And you are, could I say this, the whitest man I've ever met in my life. I mean, with his shirt off, you can see his heart like a newborn fish.
Well, this is the thing. As I went into the seat of a week, there was a discussion about.
This and I went into the sea to have a wee.
Yeah, well, I was desperate for a toilet and I was shopping and so I thought, I'm never going to make it back to the hotel, so I'll go in the sea, a little swim.
And just does seem straining just like a cat in a litter train.

There is a discussion about this because I'm very much of the opinion that you should take your trunks down. And some people, some of my friends are saying, just do it in your trunks and let see the sea. Just wash it away.
What a hell of a carnival.
And I think that's. I'm against that. I've always been against that, against that in swimming pools, everything, you know, So I.
So I. I'm against pissing in swimming pools, full stop. It doesn't matter whether you do get in, take your trunks down, all this. Don't piss. Yeah, well, fine, yeah, fish do it.

So anyway, so I'm in this. Is he trying to. Trying to urinate. And I. So I kneeled because I'm obviously very tall, so it's tricky to get deep enough for the water to mask what you're up to. So I tried to kneel down in the water, right? And I got the. I got John Thomas out, but then the water swept out again and just left me on the beach. But luckily my back was to everyone, so no one saw. So I can't think of a funnier.
Sight than Steve Merchant on his knees with his little John Thomas owl. I don't know how big it is. I've never seen it. I imagine it's in proportion to the rest of his.

This. All I'll say is I've been a little short changed, but so I. So then I got up and I waded a bit deeper in, right? And now I was sort of. I was. I was trying to Got it out. But what I didn't realize is that the waves just off the beach are really just uncontrollable. You never know what's gonna happen. So one minute they're calm and the next minute they're crazy like a tsunami. So. So suddenly I see this giant wave coming towards me, crashing towards me, and I got the cock out and everything, and it grabs. This wave comes over me and lifts me up, flips me up in the water, right? And I'm floundering around. I can't see anything because of course, I had to take my glasses off to go in the sea because I didn't want to lose her. So. So I. So I floundering around and I'm genuinely getting scared because as I try to get into shore, the wave just pulls me back again. So I'm waving to my friends on the beach with everything. Well, what I don't realize is that because I'm wearing my. Because I'm not wearing my glasses, I don't realize that I've been dragged along the beach some way and I'm not actually waving to my friends. So there's like a bunch of these beautiful women on Ipanema beach watching a pasty white man waving with his cock out. And what annoyed me was my friends were laughing. And that really angers me.
If I'd have been there, I would have burst.
But why wouldn't you have come running? Would you have come running in and help me?
Not with your knob out.
So even though I was screaming and.

Shouting, I would have thrown a rope or something or a thingy or something. There's no way I'd have. Oh, I couldn't have saved you with your glasses off in your knob out. If I ever save you, I want you to be fully dressed with your glasses on.
So you'd have just let me go? That would have been what you'd said to my parents. He had his knob out and his glasses off. There was no way I was gonna.
I can't think of a funnier sight.
Oh.
Oh, chimpanzee that. He's written it down again.

Yeah. This is where we read extracts from Kyle's diary. We've had to wrestle it from him. He's never happy. But, you know, that's the way it goes when you're doing a show as popular as this. And I'm going straight now to this entry, my man phoned and said that me Auntie Nora, classic Auntie Nora, wanted me to look on the Internet to find out what the weather would be like in Spain at the end of November. What does she want to do? Start football team.
Why?
She wanted Vanguard Nastro turf.
She likes the sort of green look, but she doesn't like the headache that comes with it. So she's just looking into getting that false grass put in there.
Brilliant.
Don't know how much it is.

Went round to Ricky's and had some chicken curry that Ricky's girlfriend Jane had made. Why doesn't he like the fact that I've got a cat and I love the cat? Why?

What do you mean you get special treatment? Sometimes we put food down for it and sometimes it gets on our lap and we stroke it.

We're not sitting.

I don't like Ricky's cat.
Oh, I can't believe.
Because every time I go around there, it goes straight from a ghoulies. Instantly.

Yeah.
But what I'm saying is, and if you're gonna criticize someone for just sitting there, having a round head and doing nothing with its life. People who live in glass houses. We've done this one.

That's like saying, why did you take pictures of anything?

Have you got to see something that small? So why would you take a picture of Steve in the sea?

No, but what, what I mean is, why. At what point are we gonna stop? Are we gonna start sort of X raying the fellas testicles and saying, well, there it is at a really young age. Where are we gonna stop?
It's because it's just pauses for causes, isn't it? Some people like to have a record of their baby in the womb. They like to show their baby they're excited about it.

Oh, Christ.

She's.
